concepts.name: Quote
concepts.description: Blocking evaluation with ' to treat expressions as data
learning_objectives: Use single quote (') to prevent evaluation of expressions
Understand the distinction between data and code in Lisp
Recognize when quote is necessary vs. when it's not
Convert between 'x shorthand and (quote x) full form
Predict the result of quoted vs. unquoted expressions

mastery_indicators.description: Can correctly place single quote before expression
mastery_indicators.test_method: Ask: 'How do you write the list (a b c) as data?'

mastery_indicators.description: Can determine which expressions need quotes
mastery_indicators.test_method: Show expressions, ask which need quotes and why

mastery_indicators.description: Can predict and explain results of quoted/unquoted forms
mastery_indicators.test_method: Ask: 'What happens if you evaluate John vs 'John and why?'

mastery_indicators.description: Understands that 'x is syntactic sugar for (quote x)
mastery_indicators.test_method: Ask: 'What special form does 'John expand to?'

examples.explanation: Quote returns its argument unevaluated. Works on both symbols and lists.
Numbers evaluate to themselves, so quote makes no difference. Same result, different reason.
Without quote, list is evaluated as function call. With quote, returned as data structure.

examples.content:
> John => *Error: JOHN is not a bound variable*
> (John Q Public) => *Error: JOHN is not a function*
examples.explanation: Without quotes, symbols are looked up as variables, lists as function calls. These fail because undefined.
Single quote is abbreviation for the quote special form

misconceptions.reality: Numbers are self-evaluating; quote is optional but redundant
Quote works on any expression: symbols, lists, numbers, etc.

misconceptions.misconception: Quote changes or modifies the value
misconceptions.reality: Quote doesn't change anything; it prevents evaluation
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Emphasize: quote returns argument literally, unevaluated

misconceptions.misconception: Quotes come in pairs like strings
misconceptions.reality: Single quote in Lisp marks beginning; end is determined by expression structure
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Explain: Lisp knows where expression ends (atom boundary or matching paren)

misconceptions.misconception: Quote is the same as a string
misconceptions.reality: Strings use double quotes and are different data type
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Compare: 'John returns symbol JOHN, "John" returns string "John"

key_insights: In Lisp, the same notation represents both code and data
Quote is the switch: turns off evaluation, treats expression as data
Self-evaluating objects (numbers, strings) don't need quotes
Quote is a special form because it must NOT evaluate its argument

concepts.name: List Accessors
concepts.description: Functions to extract elements: first, rest, second, third, etc.
learning_objectives: Use first to extract the first element of a list
Use rest to get all elements after the first
Use second, third, fourth for specific positions
Understand that rest returns a list, not an atom
Chain accessors to navigate nested list structures
Recognize that accessing beyond list end returns NIL

mastery_indicators.description: Can use first to get first element
mastery_indicators.test_method: Ask: 'How do you get the first element of (a b c)?'

mastery_indicators.description: Can use rest to get remaining elements
Understands rest always returns a list (even with one element)
mastery_indicators.test_method: Ask: 'What's the difference between (first (rest x)) and (rest x)?'

mastery_indicators.description: Can use second, third, fourth, etc.

mastery_indicators.description: Can chain multiple accessors to reach nested elements
mastery_indicators.test_method: Ask: 'How do you get Z from ((a b) (x y z))?'

mastery_indicators.description: Knows that accessing beyond list returns NIL
Can navigate complex nested list structures
mastery_indicators.test_method: Give nested list, ask to extract deeply nested element

examples.content:
> p => (JOHN Q PUBLIC)
> (first p) => JOHN
> (rest p) => (Q PUBLIC)
> (second p) => Q
> (third p) => PUBLIC
> (fourth p) => NIL
> (length p) => 3
examples.explanation: Basic accessor usage on a simple list. Note fourth returns NIL because list has only 3 elements.

examples.content:
> (setf x '((1st element) 2 (element 3) ((4)) 5))
> (length x) => 5
> (first x) => (1ST ELEMENT)
> (second x) => 2
> (third x) => (ELEMENT 3)
> (fourth x) => ((4))
examples.explanation: List with mixed atom and list elements. Accessors return whatever is at that position, whether atom or list.
Chaining accessors to reach nested elements. Read from inside out: (fourth x) gets ((4)), then (first ...) gets (4), then (first ...) gets 4.

examples.content:
> (cons 'Mr p) => (MR JOHN Q PUBLIC)
> (cons (first p) (rest p)) => (JOHN Q PUBLIC)
examples.explanation: Shows relationship between first/rest and cons: cons is the inverse operation

misconceptions.reality: rest returns everything EXCEPT the first element (as a list)
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Show: (rest '(a b c)) => (B C), not C

misconceptions.misconception: rest returns atoms when there's one element left
misconceptions.reality: rest ALWAYS returns a list, even (rest '(a b)) => (B) not B

misconceptions.misconception: Accessing beyond list length causes an error
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Show: (fourth '(a b c)) => NIL, this is valid
Show step-by-step evaluation of chained accessors

key_insights: first and rest are the fundamental list accessors (second, third are built from them)
rest always returns a list, making it safe for recursion
Accessors can be chained to navigate nested structures
NIL is returned when accessing beyond list bounds (not an error)
List accessors work on any list, regardless of what elements contain

examples.content:
(defun first-name (name)
  "Select the first name from a name represented as a list."
  (if (member (first name) *titles*)
      (first-name (rest name))
      (first name)))
examples.explanation: Recursive function that strips titles from names. Base case: first element is not a title. Recursive case: skip first element and recurse on rest.

examples.content:
> (first-name '(Madam Major General Paula Jones))
(1 ENTER FIRST-NAME: (MADAM MAJOR GENERAL PAULA JONES))
  (2 ENTER FIRST-NAME: (MAJOR GENERAL PAULA JONES))
    (3 ENTER FIRST-NAME: (GENERAL PAULA JONES))
      (4 ENTER FIRST-NAME: (PAULA JONES))
      (4 EXIT FIRST-NAME: PAULA)
    (3 EXIT FIRST-NAME: PAULA)
  (2 EXIT FIRST-NAME: PAULA)
(1 EXIT FIRST-NAME: PAULA)
PAULA
examples.explanation: Trace output showing four recursive calls, each stripping one title until reaching the base case

examples.content:
function first-name(name):
    if the first element of name is a title
        then return the first-name of the rest of the name
        else return the first element of the name
examples.explanation: Abstract pattern showing the two-part structure: test condition, then either recurse or return base value

misconceptions.reality: It's just a function call - the same function happens to call itself
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Show that recursive call is identical to any other function call

misconceptions.reality: Base case stops recursion, and each call makes progress toward it
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Trace execution showing finite number of calls, emphasize base case

misconceptions.misconception: You need to mentally track all recursive calls
misconceptions.reality: Use 'leap of faith' - trust that recursive call works, verify base case and progress
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Teach two-part correctness: (1) base case correct, (2) recursive case makes progress

misconceptions.reality: Works on any recursive data structure (trees, numbers, etc.)
misconceptions.correction_strategy: Show example on numbers: factorial, fibonacci

key_insights: Every recursive function has at least one base case (stopping condition)
Every recursive call must make progress toward the base case
Recursive functions can be proven correct without tracing all calls
The 'leap of faith': assume recursive call works, verify you use it correctly

exercises.title: Robust last-name function
exercises.prompt: Define a version of last-name that handles "Rex Morgan MD," "Morton Downey, Jr.," and whatever other cases you can think of.

tests_concepts.rationale: Requires recursive thinking to handle variable-length names with titles/suffixes
Must navigate list structure to examine and skip elements
Must define a named function with proper structure
Could use filtering approach instead of recursion

learning_opportunities: Design decisions: what counts as a 'title' vs 'suffix'?
Edge cases: single-name persons, all-title lists
Data structure choice: hardcode patterns or use data?
Multiple valid solutions with different tradeoffs
common_mistakes: Only handling prefixes (Mr, Dr) but forgetting suffixes (Jr, MD)
Not handling edge case of single-word names
Hardcoding specific titles instead of using a pattern
Forgetting to use defparameter for extensible title list

hints.hint: Think about what patterns indicate it's NOT the last name - both at the start AND end
You might need to check both first and last elements of the name
Consider using remove-if or filtering to clean the list before selecting the last name

example_solutions.code:
(defparameter *suffixes* '(Jr Sr MD PhD III IV)
  "Common name suffixes")

(defun last-name (name)
  "Select the last name, handling titles and suffixes."
  (let ((last-element (first (last name))))
    (if (member last-element *suffixes*)
        (last-name (butlast name))  ; Remove suffix, recurse
        (if (member (first name) *titles*)
            (last-name (rest name))  ; Remove title, recurse
            last-element))))  ; Found it!
example_solutions.explanation: Recursive approach: check last element for suffixes, first element for titles, recurse until clean.

example_solutions.code:
(defun last-name (name)
  "Select the last name after removing titles and suffixes."
  (let ((cleaned (remove-if 
                   #'(lambda (word) 
                       (or (member word *titles*)
                           (member word *suffixes*)))
                   name)))
    (if cleaned
        (first (last cleaned))
        (first (last name)))))  ; Fallback if everything removed
example_solutions.explanation: Functional approach: filter out titles/suffixes, then select last remaining element.

followup_questions: How would you handle hyphenated names like 'Mary-Beth'?
What if someone has multiple titles: 'Dr Prof John Smith'?
Could you extend this to extract middle names?

exercises.title: Exponentiation function
exercises.prompt: Write a function to exponentiate, or raise a number to an integer power. For example: (power 3 2) = 3² = 9.

tests_concepts.rationale: Classic recursive problem: x^n = x * x^(n-1)
Must define function with two parameters

learning_opportunities: Optimization: using x^(n/2) for even exponents
Complexity analysis: O(n) vs O(log n)
common_mistakes: Forgetting base case (infinite recursion)
Wrong base case: returning 0 or x instead of 1
Not handling n=1 case explicitly (works but inefficient)
Off-by-one errors in recursive case

hints.hint: What's the base case? What's the value of any number raised to the power of 0?
How can you express 3^5 in terms of 3^4? What operation connects them?
Advanced optimization: For even exponents, you can compute x^(n/2) once and square it. This reduces complexity from O(n) to O(log n).

example_solutions.code:
(defun power (x n)
  "Raise x to the nth power. N must be an integer >= 0."
  (if (= n 0)
      1
      (* x (power x (- n 1)))))
example_solutions.explanation: Simple recursive: base case n=0 returns 1, otherwise multiply x by x^(n-1). O(n) time.

example_solutions.code:
(defun power (x n)
  "Power raises x to the nth power. N must be an integer >= 0.
   This executes in log n time, because of the check for even n."
  (cond ((= n 0) 1)
        ((evenp n) (expt (power x (/ n 2)) 2))
        (t (* x (power x (- n 1))))))
example_solutions.explanation: Optimized: for even n, compute x^(n/2) once and square it. Reduces complexity to O(log n).

followup_questions: How would you extend this to handle negative exponents?
What if x is 0 and n is 0? (0^0 is undefined)
Can you trace the optimized version on (power 2 8)? How many multiplications?

exercises.title: Count atoms in expression
exercises.prompt: Write a function that counts the number of atoms in an expression. For example: (count-atoms '(a (b) c)) = 3. Notice that there is something of an ambiguity in this: should (a nil c) count as three atoms, or as two, because it is equivalent to (a () c)?

tests_concepts.rationale: Requires recursion on BOTH first and rest - tree structure
Must recursively descend into nested list structure
Exercise explicitly asks about nil treatment - design decision

learning_opportunities: Tree recursion pattern: recurse on BOTH parts
Design decisions: nil as atom or not?
exercises.conceptual_challenge: The nil ambiguity is intentional - teaches that specifications matter. Is nil an atom? Depends on context!
common_mistakes: Only recursing on rest, not first (misses nested atoms)
Counting empty lists as atoms
Not handling nil properly in base case
Confusion between (atom x) and (not (listp x))

hints.hint: This is different from simple list recursion - you need to look inside sublists too
You need TWO recursive calls: one on (first exp) to count atoms inside, one on (rest exp) to count the rest
Think about your base cases: What if exp is nil? What if exp is an atom? What if exp is a list?

example_solutions.code:
(defun count-atoms (exp)
  "Return the total number of non-nil atoms in the expression."
  (cond ((null exp) 0)
        ((atom exp) 1)
        (t (+ (count-atoms (first exp))
              (count-atoms (rest exp))))))
example_solutions.explanation: Treats nil as 0 atoms. Clean interpretation: empty list contributes nothing.

example_solutions.code:
(defun count-all-atoms (exp &optional (if-null 1))
  "Return the total number of atoms in the expression,
  counting nil as an atom only in non-tail position."
  (cond ((null exp) if-null)
        ((atom exp) 1)
        (t (+ (count-all-atoms (first exp) 1)
              (count-all-atoms (rest exp) 0)))))
example_solutions.explanation: Sophisticated: nil counts as atom in non-tail position (explicit nil), but not at end of list.

followup_questions: Which interpretation (count nil or not) is more useful? Why?
How would you count only symbols, excluding numbers?
Can you write this using mapcar and apply instead of explicit recursion?

exercises.title: Count occurrences anywhere
exercises.prompt: Write a function that counts the number of times an expression occurs anywhere within another expression. Example: (count-anywhere 'a '(a ((a) b) a)) => 3.

tests_concepts.rationale: Tree recursion pattern similar to count-atoms

learning_opportunities: Similar structure to count-atoms but with matching condition
Understanding eql vs equal for matching
common_mistakes: Only checking if item is first element (missing nested occurrences)
Using equal instead of eql (works but slower)
Not handling the case where tree itself equals item
Forgetting to add results from both recursive calls

hints.hint: This is very similar to count-atoms, but you're looking for a specific item
Three cases: (1) tree itself equals item, (2) tree is an atom but doesn't match, (3) tree is a list, recurse
Use eql to test equality between item and tree

example_solutions.code:
(defun count-anywhere (item tree)
  "Count the times item appears anywhere within tree."
  (cond ((eql item tree) 1)
        ((atom tree) 0)
        (t (+ (count-anywhere item (first tree))
              (count-anywhere item (rest tree))))))
example_solutions.explanation: Three-case cond: found it (1), not in atom (0), or recurse into structure adding results.

followup_questions: What's the difference between eql and equal? When would equal be necessary?
How would you find the POSITIONS of all occurrences (not just count)?
Can you modify this to find the first occurrence and return the path to it?
exercises.comparison_note: Same recursive structure as count-atoms, but with item matching instead of universal counting

exercises.title: Dot product
exercises.prompt: Write a function to compute the dot product of two sequences of numbers, represented as lists. The dot product is computed by multiplying corresponding elements and then adding up the resulting products. Example: (dot-product '(10 20) '(3 4)) = 10 × 3 + 20 × 4 = 110

tests_concepts.rationale: Can solve with recursion on two lists in parallel
Elegant solution using mapcar to multiply pairs
Use apply to sum the mapped results

learning_opportunities: Multiple valid approaches: recursive vs functional
exercises.approach_comparison: Recursive version is more explicit, functional version is more elegant. Both are correct.
common_mistakes: Forgetting base case (both lists empty)
Not handling lists of different lengths
In functional approach: forgetting #' before function names
Confusing apply and funcall

hints.hint: Think about the structure: multiply first elements, add to result of rest
What's your base case? When should recursion stop?
Alternative approach: Can you use mapcar to multiply corresponding pairs? Then how would you sum the results?
The apply function can apply + to a list of numbers: (apply #'+ '(1 2 3)) => 6

example_solutions.code:
(defun dot-product (a b)
  "Compute the mathematical dot product of two vectors."
  (if (or (null a) (null b))
      0
      (+ (* (first a) (first b))
         (dot-product (rest a) (rest b)))))
example_solutions.explanation: Recursive: multiply first elements, add to recursive call on rest. Stops when either list is empty.

example_solutions.code:
(defun dot-product (a b)
  "Compute the mathematical dot product of two vectors."
  (let ((sum 0))
    (dotimes (i (length a))
      (incf sum (* (elt a i) (elt b i))))
    sum))
example_solutions.explanation: Iterative: use loop to accumulate sum. Uses indexed access with elt.

example_solutions.code:
(defun dot-product (a b)
  "Compute the mathematical dot product of two vectors."
  (apply #'+ (mapcar #'* a b)))
example_solutions.explanation: Elegant functional: mapcar multiplies pairs element-wise, apply sums them all. Most concise!

exercises.pedagogical_value: This exercise beautifully demonstrates that functional programming can be more expressive than imperative/recursive approaches. The mapcar/apply solution is 1 line vs 4-5 for recursive.
followup_questions: What happens if the lists have different lengths?
How would you modify this to compute the cross product instead?
Can you use reduce instead of apply to sum the products?
